attributes.content:
So people have been requesting that I upload my stream footage somewhere for people to watch... and I will! I've been mulling over my options, including youtube and Mega.co.nz, but in the end the best option seems to be running my own solution. 

So I'll be hosting my own webserver with all the videos and a sort of fake youtube solution. But I'll have to buy an external hard drive soon to fit all the footage that I'll be uploading.

The tier for these videos will probably be the $6 tier, so if you're interested in this, consider pledging to that level.
attributes.title: Video Uploads!

attributes.content:
So, this month's model download is appropriately Christmassy as you would expect. I'm actually a huge Christmas fan, though this year it's been hard to get into the mood. I feel like I need a week before Christmas to adjust to the Christmas spirit before Xmas actually happens (without any work or stress). But nothing some carols and watching Die Hard can't fix!


Let's cut to the chase, attached is a zip file with Tron Bonne's model download! She's fully rigged and has the bag as a prop, enjoy!
attributes.title: Santa Tron Bonne! [Model Download]

attributes.content:
So, somehow it's already Christmas. As in, it's literally Christmas 4 AM right now as I'm writing this. This has been kind of a crazy year for me in every single way. There's been some hard times and some really good times. But all in all, 2018 has been a crazy GOOD year for me and I hope it's been a crazy good year for you too.

Now, that doesn't relate to 3D models or art or anything like that at all, but I wanted to put it out there. One of the good things that happened this year to me is this Patreon and specifically the support of all of you. Without all of you this wouldn't have happened and I really do appreciate it, it's enabled me to be able to take care of myself a little bit while being busy with school (and thus not able to take on as many commissions).

In the spirit of Christmas I wanted to give back a little bit and make something that fit the mood! Which is when I spotted the Tron Bonne art of her in her Santa outfit! Add to that a Servbot model I had lying around and you've got...

This nice little scene. The attached model is the Christmas Servbot. If you pledge $1 or higher you get access to the Tron Bonne model too!

The message got a little longer than I expected, but I hope you enjoy the models and again... 

Thank you and Merry Christmas!
attributes.title: Merry Christmas! [Servbot Model Download]

attributes.content:
This month I uploaded Pandora's model file. So that means both Pandora and Prometheus are now on this Patreon for download (for the $18 tier). Check it out if you like.

If not, I uploaded the Cappy 3D model and related files for ALL patrons this month. Similarly, expect goodies for all patrons and exclusive goodies for the $18 patrons in November as well.

It was my plan for October to do a PS1-style model and tutorial, but I didn't get to doing that. Apologies for that, but I still plan on doing that, hoping to do it for November. October has simply been excruciatingly busy for me. Didn't even get to playing Mega Man 11!

Thank you all for supporting me the way that you guys do, I really appreciate it. I hope you guys enjoy the content, and as always, let me know what you guys think!
attributes.title: HQ Prometheus and Pandora render! & Patreon Update

attributes.content:
Here's a nice freebie for September! A cappy model release for all patrons! Also includes the unity scene that applies the glow effect and particles as you can see in this image!

I originally made this model to celebrate the release of Super Mario Odyssey last year! 

Enjoy and hit me up if you guys have any questions!
attributes.title: Cappy (Super Mario Odyssey) model release!

attributes.content:
So, I've been (not so) steadily working on Metal Sonic. Here's a little WIP pic for you guys

I'm still hashing out how to do his forehead, but other than that I think it's been going well. One part I was totally unsure about (because of the lack of colored reference) was the back of the torso. The shapes are all good but the colors were a mystery, so I decided to ask Tyson Hesse (artist on Sonic Mania) and he replied!

So, now I know how to handle that. Very kind of him to help me out like that. Thanks Mr. Hesse!

Anyway, the plan is still, of course, to get this out there before the end of August. I'll probably need one or two more texturing sessions at most before we're done with him so stay tuned!

I wonder what I should cook up for next month...
attributes.title: Metal Sonic progress

attributes.content:
So for this month I'm going to release a high quality Metal Sonic model!

A WIP image! I'm going to try and match the style of the Heavy Gunner model. I'll try to make a small tutorial out of it for all patrons as well. While modeling I've been recording all the footage so you guys can expect stuff like that up here too. Twitter for some more pics: https://twitter.com/HeatPhoenix/status/1028127979388461056

Lastly, here's a question for $6 patrons: 

- If I were to upload recorded footage of me modeling various models, would you prefer sped-up timelapses or the at actual speed (even if that means uploads of several gigabytes per model?).

Lemme know in the comments or in a discord DM or whatever you want!
attributes.title: August Update!

attributes.content:
So, as you may have noticed, I recently released the Heavy Gunner model on this here patreon with animations and all included.

And now I wanted to talk about the model a little more for all patrons, not just the ones of the model download tier.

Click here for full view 

Specifically, I wanted to talk about the shading and how to do it! So, for the purpose, let's take a closer look at the thrusters on his back!

The shape is really quite simple, just a flared out bottom and a cylinder that closes at the top and has a rim near the top. The geometry is really not the interesting thing, the interesting thing is the texture.

A process gif! The colors are picked from the Heavy Gunner splash art released by SEGA. 

The process is basically, have a background coat (red in this case). Add the highlight solid (the light yellow). Get the sides with a intermediate solid color (orange). And lastly, get the edge of that with that same orange, but at 50% opacity.

The end result looking both striking, shiny and smooth!

For a closer look, check out the included attachment! It contains the thruster model and texture!

Enjoy!
attributes.title: Heavy Gunner (+ short bonus tutorial)!

attributes.content:
Friends, a while ago I modeled 3 beta Pokémon models. beta Cleffa, Pichu and Tyrogue.

Sadly, thanks to a hard drive failure I lost the files for beta Cleffa, so I can't upload that one... or really do anything with it. I have the files, but they're corrupt basically.

They're fully rigged and ready to roll! I dubbed them Piku and Hitmoncub! Check out the attached .zip!
attributes.title: Beta Pokémon Model Downloads!

attributes.content:
What you will need:
  • Blender
  • A 3-button mouse 
  • Preferably a keyboard with a numpad
  • Your rigged model from part 4!

Just like before, the attachment is a completed Kirby model with animation and all.

Intro

This final part of the Kirby-based "Blender Overview" tutorial series will be about animation! Not so much the principles of animation, I think you'd be better served learning about those some place else. No, the technical side of animation is what I'll be talking about here. Keyframes, interpolation, onion skinning and the action editor.This tutorial assumes you've completed all the tutorials before this and are comfortable with Blender. 

What we ended on, last tutorial. Kirby with a movable skeleton

Animation UI

First, let's move to another UI perspective. You may remember from Blender Overview #1 the "perspectives" drop down. It contains a list of "perspectives" that provide handy setups for the Blender UI for various workloads. And as such, there's also one called "animation"! 

Let's go ahead and click that one!

This will change the the UI to something that looks something like this!

Let's take this thing apart. 

1. The dope sheet/Action Editor -- the dope sheet shows nodes for every point in the timeline where a bone or object changes its state somehow (through rotation, movement, scaling or otherwise).

2. The curves -- these cryptic curves show how Blender is interpolating between the changing states of your bones/objects.

3. The timeline -- I've already touched upon this part of the UI, but long story short it'll play through this when you play through an animation. 

One of the first things you should do is to change where it says "Dope Sheet" into "Action Editor".

The Action Editor, as described above, will let us have separate animations on one model and edit each animation. This comes in handy in, for example, game engines where you might want to play these separate animations at different times by name, rather than by keyframe timings.

Since this is a fresh model without any animations your action editor will contain... no actions! So, let's press the "New" button. It'll make an action called "Action". Feel free to rename this into whatever you're about to animate.

Now, in the 3D view to the left, you should have Kirby up with his bones visible. We already know how to pose bones, but to go over it real quick again:

  • In Pose Mode you can pose bones
  • Right click a bone to select it, the usual controls function for manipulating the bone
  • ALT + 'R' key to reset rotation, ALT + 'G' key to reset location and ALT + 'S' key to reset scaling -- important


Keyframes

When posing a model, you'll inevitably want to save this pose as a "keyframe" in your animation. Press the 'I' key to save a keyframe to your timeline. It will ask you what part of what you've selected you want to save. LocRotScale will save Location, Rotation and Scale. 

This should create a small node in the top left window. 

Your keyframe should now show up here, as a small node. Selecting it will select that keyframe's properties for that object. 

So, if you want to select the entire keyframe (for all objects/bones) you right click the top most node. If you only want to select it for, say, the head, you just click the one in the "head" row! You can then move this node left and right along the timeline, select multiples and move them together and even scale them! The usual controls apply.

Now that we actually have a keyframe, let's talk about what keyframes actually mean.

A keyframe is a marker in time that holds information about your model (like the pose or location). In other words, if you have a keyframe at time 0 with your model just standing and another at time 10 where his arm is lifted up 90 degrees, between time 0 and 10 he'll be moving his arm towards the keyframe as displayed at time 10.

Blender will smoothly calculate how the objects will be in every frame between frame 0 and 10. You only set Keyframe 0 and 10 up, Blender does the rest. That smoothing in between, we call that "interpolation". The way it interpolates (linearly, bezier, etc) will have a significant effect on how the final animation looks.

  • Constant -- It won't change until it gets to frame 10. Frame 0-9, Kirby sits. Frame 10, Kirby stands.
  • Linear -- No smoothing, it just linearly moves all the bones to their final position.
  • Bezier -- Smooths the animation at the start and at the end. Very commonly used.

These are the ones you'll probably use the most often. Experiment with the other interpolation modes for the effect you want!

Changing the interpolation of a keyframe is easy! Just select the keyframe(s) (in the top left) and press Key (next to where it says "Action Editor") -> Interpolation Mode -> [Interpolation Mode that you want].

Another useful thing are "Keying sets". When you press the 'I' key to make a new keyframe Blender continually asks you what you want to save. What if you just always want to save the same properties?

At the bottom of the window, you'll find a small section that literally has a set of keys as an icon. Clicking that drop-down (drop-up?) will reveal a set of options. These are "keying sets". Clicking one will make it so that whenever you press the 'I' key it will automatically create a keyframe saving those properties of what you have selected.

I usually go with LocRotScale.

Animation

Now that we have the tools to animate, let's put together some frames.

Let's try a simple waving animation. Basically, Kirby will stand, he'll wave his left hand and he'll go back to standing.

A very simple animation indeed. In fact, there's much more you can do with this. Like maybe Kirby's body can swing, or maybe he'll get up on his tippy-toes, but you should always start small.

So, this is what my timeline looks like for this animation.

  • Frame 1 -- Neutral standing position
  • Frame 15 -- Arm up
  • Frame 30 -- Arm down
  • Frame 45 -- Arm up
  • Frame 60 -- Neutral

The green line is where you currently are on the timeline. Drag it here and there and watch your model animate. Pressing play will automatically play the timeline over the gray area. If you want to extend or shorten the gray area, put your mouse on the timeline and press the 'E' key. It'll then adjust the timeline to where cursor is, only play that far and no further.

To create this animation, put the cursor on frame 0 and create a "Neutral standing frame". Then put the cursor on 60 and copy and paste that standing frame. You can copy the position/rotation/scale of a bone and paste in  a different frame with Ctrl + C and Ctrl + V.

Let's press Play!

Too fast? Too slow? Remember, you can select all the nodes in the top-right dope sheet/action editor and scale them. Scaling them to be closer together will make it faster. Scaling them to be further apart will make it slower.

Remembers, the 'B' key activates rectangle select

That should do it! Now you've got a Kirby. A textured Kirby. A rigged Kirby. An animated Kirby!

Here's the animation I did when I finished my version of this Kirby model:

Now that you've got the tools to build stuff, let your imagination run wild! Model something crazy or animate something sublime... and don't forget to show me!

Fin

Thank you all for following this series of tutorials through, it's been something special being able to give a bit of the knowledge back to the people supporting me. If you guys have any questions at all about Blender or about 3D stuff, just send me a message anytime of day and I'll be sure to try my best to help you.
attributes.title: Blender Overview #5

attributes.content:
What you will need:
  • Blender
  • A 3-button mouse 
  • Preferably a keyboard with a numpad
  • Your model from part 3!

As always, the attachment is a fully finished Kirby that you can use as reference or for well... anything else! But, if you want to learn it's definitely better to work with your own model!

Intro

In this part of the Blender Overview series of tutorials we'll be tackling adding an armature to your model. An armature is a "skeleton" of sorts, it'll map parts of your model to parts of this skeleton. The arm to the arm bone, the neck to the neck bone and so on. Using this skeleton we'll be able to pose the model and eventually even animate it! Animation in 3D is, after all, just a collection of poses playing in sequence.

Our starting point for this tutorial!

Let's discuss armatures first! An armature of a model is a set of bones that will (eventually) move your model's mesh as you move the bones. You can build an armature without a model to go with it or you can build it after the model's done. I usually do the latter.

Two of the most important modes involved with armatures are "Edit Mode"  (which you're most likely already intimately familiar with by now) and "Pose Mode". Pose mode is exclusive to armatures and in pose mode we can move the bones as we want (and moving the mesh with it).

Selection, movement and so on work the same as they do in all the other modes. 

Starting a skeleton

First off, we need to learn how to make "bones". Your armature is made up out of a bunch of bones and we start with the "root" bone. The root bone is the start from which everything else branches out. When we animate or pose the model moving the root bone will move the entire armature (and the entire model).

To create a bone, move to Object Mode and hit Shift + A. Then select Armature -> Single Bone. This will create a single bone wherever the cursor is. For your root bone, you'll probably want this to be centered so make sure to center your cursor (Shift + S -> Cursor to Center).

What the hell does "Force Field" even do?

This first bone will serve as our root. At this point it's probably a good idea to start thinking about what bones we'll even want in our end result.

Planning ahead can be as simple as a doodle over a screenshot as demonstrated below:

A mock-up of what the final skeleton could look like

Root bone in the middle and a bone for each of his arms and a bone for each of his legs. Simple as that. Maybe we'll add another bone for his "head".

 After creating your bone, you may notice that it's sticking straight through Kirby and you can't even see most of it. 


Enable X-Ray in the Armature properties in the properties menu. This will allow you to see the bones through the model. 

Now that we can actually see the bone let's stick it in a sensible position. The root bone will not actually have any part of Kirby associated with it. It is simply a bone outside of the skeleton that you can move the entire model with, think of it like having a little action figure (it's not a doll!) with a handle on the back. The handle isn't really part of the figure.

I placed it directly behind Kirby. Sometimes I place the root bone as a connected piece of the skeleton sticking out of the character's back, but Kirby is quite small and dense. When you have a character like that it's wise to get the root bone out of the way.

An example of such a root bone

You'll want to name your bones appropriately for future reference. Next to the Armature properties, there are the "Bone" properties. Where you can name them and also set their relationship to other bones.

The menu while in "Pose Mode". Options regarding editing are grayed out

An armature

Now it's time for our second bone! And the start of a bonafide skeleton!

Bones have a "head" and a "tail". You can't connect two bones by their heads or two bones by their tails. The fat end is the head and the thin end is the tail! When posing a bone the head will stay in place and the tail will move. 

While in edit mode, selecting a bone (the usual right click) and pressing E while create a new bone that is directly connected to (parented by) the selected bone. New bones will come from the tail of the selected bone.

 In most cases you'll want to create a link of bones with the new bone starting at the joint of whatever it is you're giving an armature (like an elbow). 

An example layout!

In this case, we want the bone to be disconnected and not connected. The root bone, after all, is disconnected and far away from Kirby's actual body! So, untick "Connected" in the bone properties as shown below.

Now you can move the bone anywhere freely with G.

I went with this bone positioning. The second bone should be parented (but not connected) to the root bone. Why? Because if the root bone moves, you want EVERYTHING to move, including the head. So, in that sense you want all bones in the armature to be rooted to the root bone. 

Does that mean the root bone will be the parent of every single bone? Fortunately, this is not the case! For example, if we connect our arm bones to our "head" bone (bone 2) because we want the arms to move when the head does, the arms will ALSO move when the head moves because the root moved.

Basically, all children of a bone will move in conjunction with the parents and grandparents and so on!

The right half of the skeleton finished

As with the model itself, it's not necessary to create more than one half of the bones (if the armature is symmetrical). So, this is the right half that we're aiming for. 

The fat end is what the bone will rotate around, so make sure that the fat end is in a position where it makes sense for the bone to rotate around. Why did I stick Kirby's arm bone so far inward? Well...

This wouldn't be possible otherwise!

Use the above images as reference and try to add the arm and feet bone. The arm bone should be parented to the head bone (but not connected)! And the feet bone should be parented to the root. 

Make sure to name them appropriately! I tend to name them things like hand.l ("l" for left) and foot.r ("r" for... you get it).

Symmetry

Now that we've finished the half of the skeleton, we'll have to duplicate that half, mirror it and rename it. Sounds like a lot of work.

Luckily, there's a tool for that ™ ! It's called "Symmetrize". It duplicates, mirrors AND renames the bones. All in one action.

You can find it at the bottom bar in Edit Mode. Select the bones you want to symmetrize (in our case, the hand and the foot). And then click Armature -> Symmetrize! 

Bang. Suddenly, we have a completed skeleton! The names should also be correct.

Weights

Now we come to the last and most time-consuming part of rigging (as we call giving a model a skeleton), weighting! Also known as "weight painting". 

First, we must parent our model to the armature! In Object Mode, select your model and then Shift + select (Shift is for selecting multiple things, as you know) your armature. Then press Ctrl + P. It'll pop up a parenting menu, select "With Automatic Weights".

Automatic weights will try to automatically assign sensible "weights" to each bone, this almost never works out but it gives you a good base to work with.

The mesh of you model can be "linked" to a part of your skeleton or multiple bones of your skeleton. The "weight" determines how strongly it will react to movement of that bone. 

A WIP weight painted Kirby

Red is high weight, blue is no weight. You want stuff you DON'T want to move with that bone to be blue and you want stuff that you do want to move to be red. Stuff that you want to move with multiple bones (like around the elbow for an arm) to be half-way weighted for both bones.

An example of weighting the two bones of an elbow joint

In our case, though, we can just settle for weighting each bone to its relevant part and leave it at that.

Now, how do we actually enter this "Weight painting mode"? First, select the bone you want to weight paint for, then select your mesh (right click on the model itself) and press Ctrl + Tab. This will enter Weight Paint mode with that bone as the selected bone. Ctrl + right click on another bone will move to that bone, a regular right click won't do.

Switching modes and a display of my weights

You'll note that there probably is some weight set to the bone. Try moving the bone around, something will move. And it'll probably look awful. Left clicking will paint over the current weights with your current brush.

Editing your brush is possible in the top left. "Weight" corresponds with the weight you're applying when you paint, set it to something low for more control. The brush will not paint "through" objects.

"Blend" determines the blend mode of your brush. You'll find this to be similar to what you might get in Paint Tool SAI. "Auto Normalize" will make it so that the combined weight on a certain part of the model can never exceed "1". Weight ranges from 0 (blue) to 1 (red). If you have two models applying force on one part of the model, ideally they'd both be at 0.5 each (or some ratio that adds up to 1.0).

To fix that we have to make the weighting be exactly what we want, not just approximately. Like I said before, we'll want the arm bone to correspond only with the arm and so on.

To achieve our goal we'll use a handy feature called "face masking". Face masking makes it so that only the faces you select will be painted. And another feature called "Set Weight". This will set the weight of whatever it is you've selected to EXACTLY the weight chosen in your brush.

So, first off, set the weight to 0 and make sure the root bone doesn't have any weight on any part of the model (Press A to select all -> Shift + K). The entire model should now be blue when you select the root bone.

Now, let's paint the hand. Since the model has two layers, you should make sure that both layers are selected when apply the weight. 

Make sure to hide the parts of the model you don't need to make things easier on you (select something and then press the 'H' key). Another tip is that selection in Edit Mode carries over to Weight Paint mode (same with hiding). 

So, hide everything but the arm in Edit Mode. Then switch back to Weight Paint mode. Now, select the arm nub, make sure the correct bone is selected and then press Shift + K to apply the 1.0 weight to the hand! It should end up looking like this:

Make sure that the arm is the only part of the model that has any weight for that specific bone. Now, repeat the process for each of the bones (you can refer back to the gif above to see what needs to be painted for which bone).

After painting both arms, both legs and the head (orb... body thing) you should always test out the bones before moving on! Try to break your rig as best as you can! It's better to find the flaws early on.

For an easier time posing, you can change the display mode for the bones to "Stick".

Outro

Sadly, no bonus this time. Or is there? 

I have one last surprise, I recorded this entire series of tutorials! So you'll be able to watch all of this unfold in real time when I get to uploading these video files. I'll put some music under it. They're a bit too long for me to narrate but I think they'll serve as pretty good reference material while working on your own Kirbies!

As always, don't hesitate to ask me any questions you might have ask either here or on discord or anywhere else! At any time!

Thanks for reading and hit that like button if you got this far! Mad kudos!
attributes.title: Blender Overview #4

attributes.content:
Hey everyone! As usual, thanks for stickin' around and all that good stuff.

So, the content vote ended (like last week) and the end result was more tutorials! 


This means we'll be finishing off Kirby this month. I also have a video version of every tutorial up until now (and then some) but editing those will take me a little bit longer so no real schedule for that.

Lastly, I've been wondering if I should run that poll every month or if I should start alternating between tutorials/a model on a month-by-month basis. I would want patrons who are looking forward to both types of content to be satisfied.

People would still be able to vote, just on what kind of tutorial or which character I'd be modeling that month!

Let me know what you guys think in the comments or on Discord!
attributes.title: June Content!

attributes.name: HeatPhoenix
attributes.summary:
Hi there, my name is Zacharia but you probably know me as HeatPhoenix, a game developer and 3D artist. First of all, I want to thank you for looking at this page and considering my Patreon.



You may know me from Mega Man Battle Network 3D, one of my other video game projects or maybe you've just enjoyed checking out my models!

So what is this Patreon for?
  1. Supporting me making new models and game content for you to enjoy!
  2. Special rewards as a thank for you contributing!
  3. Tutorials and instruction on how to create 3D art in my style and games!
Pledging above the Model S tier even grants you access to my 3D model files! You're free to use them in any non-commercial use case.



With enough support I'll be able to keep up modeling high quality 3D models and animations that you can both enjoy and will help me improve my craft. Here are some examples of some models I have made in the past.



And check out some characters I'd LOVE to do with your support! Can you imagine them in 3D dimensions with 100% of my love and attention? And you'd be able to get the files too and check out every angle!



Again, thank you for reading and I hope you'll support me in my quest for excellent 3D models.

Profile image by @Tentawful
attributes.thanks_msg:
Thank you so SO much! You're helping both my dream and (hopefully) yours come true! I don't know if it's because you love the games I make or the art I create but one way or another, we're in for a hell of a ride.

Let me know if there's anything I can do to make this Patreon even more rewarding for you!

attributes.description:
• Thank you for supporting me. I really do appreciate that!
  • You get access to all Patron exclusive tutorial resources (including model files)!
attributes.title: Supporter Man

attributes.description:
• You get to vote on what project I tackle next!

AND all previous rewards!!
attributes.title: Supporter.EXE

attributes.description:
• You get exclusive access to the actual 3D model files of the models I work on for this Patreon!
  • You may use them for any non-commercial purpose you'd like!

 AND all previous rewards!
attributes.title: Model S(upporter)
